news_header: India's central bank cuts interest rates for the first time in nearly five years to stimulate growth amid slowing GDP.
news_original_title: India cuts interest rates for the first time in five years
news_text: The Reserve Bank of India has reduced its repo rate from 6.5% to 6.25% to address slowing economic growth, which is projected to hit a four-year low of 6.7%. The RBI governor stated the policy stance remains 'neutral' to allow for further support of growth. The rate cut may lower borrowing costs for consumers and businesses. This decision follows previous measures to inject liquidity into the banking system and a tax cut for the middle class, despite challenges from global uncertainties and a depreciating currency.
